user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_m_algo:
```c
static enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiAlgo3
get_m_algo (void)
{
  if (force_md5)
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_MULT_ALGO3_MD5;
  else if (force_sha256)
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_MULT_ALGO3_SHA256;
  else if (force_sha512_256)
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_MULT_ALGO3_SHA512_256;

  /* No forced algorithm selection, let MHD to use default */
  return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_MULT_ALGO3_ANY_NON_SESSION;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
/* No forced algorithm selection, let MHD to use default */
  return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_MULT_ALGO3_ANY_NON_SESSION;
explanation:
Unreachable-code risk in this function hinges on the compile-time or run-time values of the force_* identifiers. If any of force_md5, force_sha256, or force_sha512_256 are (effectively) constant true at compile time (e.g. #defined or constant-initialized) or if program logic guarantees one branch is always taken, subsequent branches or the final return may be unreachable. The fragments flagged are the conditional branches and the final return because each return can make following code unreachable; these should be inspected to determine whether any of the conditions are constant or guaranteed and thus create unreachable code.

Other pieces of the function (the function signature, braces, and the else keywords by themselves) are not separately reported because they are not independent executable statements that could be unreachable—their behavior is encompassed by the conditional/return fragments listed above. No other executable statements exist in the function to inspect for Rule 2.1.
